ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Information about female rulers from around the world and throughout history; historical writing skills

Not only did I learn a lot about the cultures and history of the various queens we learned about, I developed many insights on the interaction of gender and how history is recounted through this lens.

- critical reading skills
- broader understanding of the world
- highlighting gender theory

History 056 was an incredible course that gave me a completely new perspective and scope in looking at the history of rulership in relation to gender, power, and race. I gained new skills that helped me read long documents more efficiently. I am now able to pinpoint main arguments of long texts both secondary and primary better. I also gained new skills in writing from the three essays we wrote, as well as new experience in research.
This course grew my understanding not just of individual royal women, but also of monarchical rule at large and governmental systems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is perfect. I am so sad Professor Hill is leaving Yale. It is a great loss that other students will never have a chance to take this course with him again.

Strengths: well organized, thoughtfully run, clear expectations, engaging content and discussions, connections to modern media

Weaknesses: some readings felt unnecessarily long/irrelevant

Even as someone who isn't a typically humanities/history-oriented person, I found this course very approachable and rewarding! I think the format of the course and the dedication of Professor Hill to making the classroom space a welcoming one was a great strength!

- strengths: interesting discussions in class, interesting readings
- weaknesses: readings are too long

This course was very well organized. Each week featured a different queen and the topics studied were ordered chronologically, giving us a good sense of how things changed/stayed the same across different time periods and regions. The queens we studied also came from very diverse backgrounds, and I studied in depth about historical figures I hadn't heard from before in very Eurocentric curriculums. This course did a great job combatting that and taught us that queenship is a phenomenon that occurred and still occurs around the world, and both historical and modern conceptions of it are very much influenced by colonialism and race.
I would have preferred spending less time in class going over the facts of each queens life.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It's a fun course and Prof. Hill is great. I learned about many historical figures I'd never heard of.

Yes - I think that we don't get to learn enough about other places, especially in history courses, and the fact that we get to learn about places like Aceh and about the colonization of Hawaii is very stimulating.

Yes! I highly recommend this class to any student interested in history, political science, and/or gender studies. This course is a great opportunity to learn about women in rulership, who are often underrepresented in mainstream historical narratives.
